articles.headline: E.P.A. Finds More VW Cheating Software, Including in a Porsche
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency also said it found the software, designed to cheat on emissions tests, on more Volkswagen and Audi diesel cars than previously disclosed.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency also said it found the software, designed to cheat on emissions tests, on more Volkswagen and Audi diesel cars than previously disclosed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency said on Monday that it had discovered emissions-cheating software on more Volkswagen and Audi cars than previously disclosed and, for the first time, also found the illegal software in one of the carmaker’s high-end Porsche models.

articles.headline: Under Pressure to Stand Out, Jeb Bush Tries for Reset
articles.snippet: Speaking in Tampa, Mr. Bush offered cheery recollections of his time as governor and laments over a flawed campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Speaking in Tampa, Mr. Bush offered cheery recollections of his time as governor and laments over a flawed campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Jeb Bush has played the wide-eyed optimist, anointing himself the “joyful tortoise” in a campaign season low on joy and reptiles.

articles.headline: New U.S.-Backed Alliance to Counter ISIS in Syria Falters
articles.snippet: Ten days of interviews and front-line visits made clear that an alliance entrusted with beating jihadists in northern Syria faces daunting political and logistical challenges.
articles.abstract: Ten days of interviews and front-line visits made clear that an alliance entrusted with beating jihadists in northern Syria faces daunting political and logistical challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: EIN EISSA, Syria — Weeks after the Obama administration canceled a failed Pentagon program to train and arm Syrian rebels to combat the Islamic State, American officials announced a new effort to equip ground forces in Syria to fight the jihadists.

articles.headline: Illinois District Violated Transgender Student’s Rights, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: The student, who identifies as a girl, had not been allowed to change and shower in the girls’ locker room without restrictions.
articles.abstract: The student, who identifies as a girl, had not been allowed to change and shower in the girls’ locker room without restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Federal education authorities, staking out their firmest position yet on an increasingly contentious issue, found Monday that an Illinois school district violated anti-discrimination laws when it did not allow a transgender student who identifies as a girl and participates on a girls’ sports team to change and shower in the girls’ locker room without restrictions.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Wall Street Sours on Whole Foods Market
articles.snippet: Even as sales of organic products are taking off, the share price of Whole Foods has fallen 50 percent from its high this year, as investors worry about its prices and more competition.
articles.abstract: Even as sales of organic products are taking off, the share price of Whole Foods has fallen 50 percent from its high this year, as investors worry about its prices and more competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of organic and natural products are soaring — but you would never know it from the share price of Whole Foods Market, the premier purveyor of such merchandise.

articles.headline: Wave of New-Car Recalls Raises Questions for Takata Airbags
articles.snippet: Honda’s announcement of the recall of 515 CR-Vs from 2016 led Senator Bill Nelson of Florida to ask whether any Takata airbag inflaters were safe.
articles.abstract: Honda’s announcement of the recall of 515 CR-Vs from 2016 led Senator Bill Nelson of Florida to ask whether any Takata airbag inflaters were safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: As automakers struggle to repair millions of cars with airbags made by Takata that might explode and spew metal fragments, the recalls continue to widen and now extend even to the newest models.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Bobby Kotick’s Activision Blizzard to Buy King Digital, Maker of Candy Crush
articles.snippet: At $18 a share, or about $5.9 billion, King will sell at a discount to the $22.50 a share that it fetched during its initial offering last year.
articles.abstract: At $18 a share, or about $5.9 billion, King will sell at a discount to the $22.50 a share that it fetched during its initial offering last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest names in traditional video games is making its boldest step yet into the fast-growing world of mobile gaming with the multibillion-dollar acquisition of a onetime darling.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: In Religious Arbitration, Scripture Is the Rule of Law
articles.snippet: Organizations can compel their customers and employees to resolve disputes in arbitration proceedings bound not by state or federal law, but by religious edict.
articles.abstract: Organizations can compel their customers and employees to resolve disputes in arbitration proceedings bound not by state or federal law, but by religious edict.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months before he took a toxic mix of drugs and died on a stranger’s couch, Nicklaus Ellison wrote a letter to his little sister.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Ahmad Chalabi, Iraqi Politician Who Pushed for U.S. Invasion, Dies at 71
articles.snippet: Mr. Chalabi is perhaps the Iraqi most associated with President George W. Bush’s decision to invade the country and topple its longtime dictator, Saddam Hussein.
articles.abstract: Mr. Chalabi is perhaps the Iraqi most associated with President George W. Bush’s decision to invade the country and topple its longtime dictator, Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ahmad Chalabi, the Iraqi politician who from exile helped persuade the United States to invade Iraq in 2003, and then unsuccessfully tried to attain power as his country was nearly torn apart by sectarian violence, died on Tuesday at his home in Baghdad. He was 71.

articles.headline: Neuropolitics, Where Campaigns Try to Read Your Mind
articles.snippet: Technologies like facial coding, biometrics and brain imaging are being used by politicians worldwide to try to measure their standing with voters.
articles.abstract: Technologies like facial coding, biometrics and brain imaging are being used by politicians worldwide to try to measure their standing with voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the lobby of a Mexico City office building, people scurrying to and fro gazed briefly at the digital billboard backing a candidate for Congress in June.

articles.headline: China Aims for 6.5% Economic Growth Over Next 5 Years, Xi Says
articles.snippet: The target is an apparent attempt to temper expectations that the nation’s economy will rebound to anything near the double-digit growth of recent decades.
articles.abstract: The target is an apparent attempt to temper expectations that the nation’s economy will rebound to anything near the double-digit growth of recent decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China announced on Tuesday that the Communist Party and the national government had set a 6.5 percent target for annual economic growth from 2016 to 2020.
